dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run-down place. A dozen 12-year-old BOYS sit at old- fashioned desks. These are not Hasidim, but Orthodox Jews normal American kids in yarmulkes. The teacher, RAV ZINGESSER is young, overweight, acnescarred, good-humored

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why did the Holy One -- blessed be He -- do this? Why did he ask Abraham to sacrifice his only son, whom he loved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two boys off to one side: AVI (a smart, tough, brownnose) and DANNY (the eternal dissident) argue under their breat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaac wasn't his only son. Ishmael was his son, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only son he loved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, they only kill them when they love them...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (up front; answering Zingesser) It was a test of Abraham's faith. Of his devotion to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not about Abraham's faith. It's about God's power. God says, "You know how powerful I am? I can make you do anything I want, no matter how stupid. Even kill your own son. Because I'm everything, you're nothing."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITTERS. Danny looks around at his classmates: nerds, wankers, nose-pickers. Two kids in back furtively read th racing form under their desks. He hates them for their indifference as much as he despises Stuart's piety or Avi ass-kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Danny, if HaShem is everything, and we are nothing how are we to judge His actions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have free will and intelligence -- which God allegedly gave us....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, God never lets Abraham kill Isaac. He provides the ram so that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I think that's a lie. I think he did kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?! Based on what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's midrash supporting this. My father read a book by Shalom Spiegel that -- Isaac actually died and was reborn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one follows that midrash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do; I follow it. But okay, say God provided the ram. So what? Once Abraham raised the knife, in his heart it was as if he'd killed him. He could never forget that. And neither could Isaac. Look at him: he's traumatized, he's a putz for the rest of his life. By the end he can't tell Jacob from Esau....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids laugh. Zingesser CRACKS a ruler against a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your language....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising impassioned) I think the whole Jewish people were permanently scarred by what happened on Mt. Moriah, and we still live in terror....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear of God is the beginning of wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear of God makes you afraid of everything. All the Jews are good at is being afraid. And being sacrificed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooo. CRACK, CRACK, CRACK. Even the guys with the sports pages are shocked by that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you believe in God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the only one here who does believe. You say he's mysterious, yet merciful. I see him for the power- drunk madman He is. And we're supposed to worship such a Deity?? I say Never! I say...fight him. I say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ruler has been CRACKING from "power-drunk" on.... Now Zingesser grabs Danny, yanks him out of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avi -- ask Rabbi Springer to come remove Danny from the class....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avi rises, grinning, as...Danny struggles wildly to get f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, if you had come out of Egypt, you would have been destroyed in the desert with those who worshipped the Golden Calf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let Him destroy me now. Let Him crush me like the conceited bully He is. (to the ceiling) Go ahead. Kill me. Here I am. Do it!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class sits frozen in terror, waiting for God to kill Danny. But nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny runs down the steps alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny walking home alone. He sees TWO KIDS (older, toughe blonder) coming toward him. He slips off his yarmulke and slants across the street. The kids slant that way. He hea a RUMBLING, looks up at an ELEVATED TRAIN entering a stat He runs up the steps toward the SHRIEKING train....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train passes above used car lots, discount furniture stores, residential side streets...finally pulls into a station. The doors open. People file on, the CAMERA letti them go by until it spots a tall, thin COLLEGE STUDENT in YARMULKE. Danny grown up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN with him as he sits, opens an organic chemistry text. doors close. The train starts up, but the Jewish boy hard notices; he is already reading. He sways with the motion the car, half-hidden by other passengers. We realize he i being watched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ANGLE: another YOUNG MAN, standing -- a "SUEDE-HE (his hair cut so short it's like a fine fabric).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUEDE-HEAD'S POV: THE JEWISH BOY pushes his glasses back his nose, wipes the nose with a handkerchief, puts the handkerchief away, and all the time his eyes have not lef the page. Suede-head steps between passengers and stands directly over the Jewish boy. He looks down at the yarmul pinned to the stiff, wavy hair, at the oversized shirt collar, scrawny neck, prominent Adam's apple, pimples, dandruff, ingrown facial hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps closer, crowding the boy's knees. The boy shifts little without looking up. Subtly but relentlessly, Suede head pursues him along the bench until, unable to slide farther, the boy flattens his legs against the seat. Sued head presses into the boy's knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy accidentally bumps a BUSINESSMAN to Suede-head's left. The man (late 30s, Wall Street Journal, African- American) looks from the boy to Suede-head and understand at once what is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suede-head stares right back -- and the BUSINESSMAN retur to his paper. Suede-head eases him aside and steps on the boy's shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wingtip wiggles back and forth, finally working free. The boy still hasn't looked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUEDE-HEAD & THE JEWISH BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: swaying, locked in a strange, silent intimacy. Suede-head forces the boy into ever more contorted postures, increasingly ridiculous denials of what is happening. And the boy not only never stops reading the chemistry text, keeps highlighting relevant passages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train slows. The boy closes the book, caps the highlighter, gathers his things and manages to stand up, wriggling awkwardly around Suede-head. The doors open, he gets off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up a long escalator, the Jewish boy riding down toward us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suede-head arrives on the run at the top, races down a flight of stairs, vaults the bannister, slides down a met slope....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lands on his feet and comes to stand at the foot of the escalator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy rides inexorably down. At the bottom, he tries to around Suede-head who blocks this way, then another, driv him into a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy realizes he has nowhere to go -- finally turns to face his tormentor. Their eyes meet for the first time. H is actually bigger than Suede-head, but not nearly as str He won't fight, is simply acknowledging what he can no longer deny. There is even an odd relief that disgusts Suede-head more than all the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking kike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slaps him in the face. He stumbles backward. As Suede- head goes to hit him again, the boy holds his books in fr of him. Suede-head punches the books straight into his fa The boy falls, curls into a fetal position. Suede-head ki him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up.... Get the fuck up....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't budge. Suede-head punches him repeatedly until h hears VOICES approaching. He runs back up the stairs to t train and only as we FOLLOW him do we realize that he is protagonist. This is Danny grown up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like his brain, the room is at once crowded and tidy and so far as we can see, neither windows nor doors. Shelves books, CDs, magazines, videotapes loom over a neatly made

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, in briefs and boots, is lifting weights. The phone rings. A machine picks up: no outgoing message, only a BE Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this working? I'm trying to reach Danny Balint...Danny, it's Vicki, we met at Happy Jack's last month...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps doing curls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping maybe we could...get together again... Give me a call -- 718-555-0193.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. A moment later Danny finishes the set, gasp for air, heart pounding, muscles throbbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A radio is playing the news. Danny sits at a small desk, the phone and browsing the Internet, a take-out menu besi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Is it completely vegetarian? ...What do they make the stock from?... Not chicken, you're sure?... And no dairy... No, no cheese I don't eat cheese... Yeah, all right. And the tropical fruit shake... How long?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over this we see: COMPUTER SCREEN: GLIMPSES OF PASSING PH

dialogues.speaker: OF THE HOUSE...DYNAMITE CAN BE STOLEN FROM CONSTRUCTION
dialogues.text: SITES & ROAD CREWS, PARTICULARLY IN MOUNTAINOUS AREAS CURTIS ZAMPF IN NYC 5/18...JEWISH PIMPS, DRUG DLRS &

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He HIGHLIGHTS the item about Curtis Zampf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tough working-class Queens bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men drink in clusters, including a group of skinheads.... Danny takes a place alone at the bar, drawing furtive attention from the regulars. When the BARTENDER finally comes over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vodka tonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strange call for this place. As he waits, Danny turns a watches the skinheads enough to make them aware of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls watch him, too. The skins don't like that. One them (Billings) seems ready to do something about it. The others try to calm him, and when they look back, Danny ha left. He barely touched the drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skins are puzzled, but one indicates his watch: time go. They gather their stuff....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out the front of the train as it rushes toward Manhattan. A dramatic sky rises above the skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three skins -- O.L., CARLETON, BILLINGS -- walk up an East Side street. Billings is telling a story....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...So she takes the pants in back -- where they try them on? And I think fuck it....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you shitting me?? Right in the store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been giving me the eye. She's hot. So I wait till the owner goes up front....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, O.L. starts to SPRAY PAINT a crude SWASTIKA onto a BUS KIOSK. A VOICE startles them....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They jump, turn. Danny steps out of the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating swastika) What do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming toward them) Who am I?? Who are you, you schmucks, you can't even make a decent swastika.... Give me the paint. (O.L. looks to his friends) Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's will is stronger; O.L. hands over the spray can. Danny shakes it, critiques O.L.'s rendering....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruff but avuncular) It's too squared off. You got to orient it up and down, diamond-shaped, like this.... (sprays an excellent swastika) ...The arms go clockwise. (hands the can back) You're going to Curtis Zampf; me, too. Let's go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange looks: how did he know about Curtis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Where I grew up in South Boston twenty years ago, when a kid walked down the street, everyone knew who he was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand but threadbare. The skins enter: O.L. like a child, Carleton like a sardonic adolescent, Billings like a revolutionary, Danny like an uncrowned prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CURTIS ZAMPF is addressing a dozen or so guests. He is 40 but appears younger; with rough good looks, longish hair a leather jacket, he seems more like an aging rock star o sexy novelist that a standard-issue American Nazi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...If he ran out in front of a car, some old Mick'd yell at him, "Jimmy Dunne, get back on that sidewalk and stay there...."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does the Boston Irish accent so well, everybody laughs Up front we notice the only WOMAN in the room. She is in 40s, regal, beautiful, forbidding. Her name is LINA MOEBI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The day he graduated high school, he'd go see his uncle down at the gas works, or the priest's brother in the shipyard, get his apprentice papers, eight years later he'd be making $16.50 an hour, have four kids, play ball on Sundays in Columbus Park, and when he died, the whole town'd get drunk and cry over him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd -- nonunion electricians, white taxi drivers, unemployed bookkeepers, failed academics, off-duty cops - listens quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this, a young woman (CARLA) appears from the rear the apartment, heading for the kitchen with a coffee cup a history book. She glances into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Today, when that kid walks down the street it's full of trash and half the faces are black. The shipyard's closed, all the jobs at the gas works are set-asides, and by the time he drops out of school, he can barely get a job at Burger King. So he drinks, smokes crack, and when he hangs himself on the front porch at twenty-three, the only people at his wake are a couple of buddies and his mother. The boy's father won't find out he's dead till six months later. (beat) The soul of this country is being destroyed, and all the government can offer is free trade, mutual funds and IPOs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like a leftist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to be one.... No, seriously, I called myself an anarchist. I stood up for the oppressed. I opposed state power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you still?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I oppose the present state because it's weak. It has been ever since the left emasculated it over Vietnam. But I think the average man is crushed less by accumulated capital than the loss of community or real leadership, the personal emptiness he simply cannot fill on his own.... (matter-of-fact) That's why I'm a fascist. It's the only form of government that addresses our deepest needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Danny -- who has spotted Carla -- begins to clap few others join in. Danny raises his hand; Curtis nods to him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think the fascism of the twenty-first century will look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone -- including Carla -- turns to see who asked tha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More cultural than political.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decentralized, nonviolent, increasingly mainstream. We'll see antiabortion, anti-immigration groups form alliances with the gun lobby, Christian identity types, tax resisters and even some libertarians....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd seems impressed, but restless and bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stirring: many share the concern. Lina watches closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the time for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmurs of surprise, disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I disagree. (glances at Carla) I think race is central to everything we're talking about. (murmurs of agreement) Spiritual life comes from race. From the blood. Without that, we're no better than the Jews....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The magic word. The whole room comes alive. Zampf grimace

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the Jews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you read Toynbee? Spengler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody reads that stuff anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too difficult?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too Christian. You know Jameson? Paul Virilio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, the modern world is a Jewish disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disease? What disease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abstraction. They're obsessed with abstraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stops the conversation. But Carla is intrigued; here someone whose mind moves in strange and interesting realm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you propose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The questioner is a young man (GUY DANIELSEN), better spo than the others. Danny feels all eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killing Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tremor of fear and excitement ripples through the room. Zampf glances at Mrs. Moebius; she is watching Danny inte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a catastrophic mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People hate Jews. Do you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They used to. Today it's not an issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but deep down, beneath the "tolerance" they learn on television, nothing's changed. The very word makes their skin crawl. (around the room people nod) It isn't even hate, really. It's more the way we feel when a rat runs across the floor. We want to step on it. Crush it. We don't even know why. It's a physical reaction. Everyone feels it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which ones would you kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prominent Jews. Who are either symbols in themselves or who represent aspects of the Jewish character people despise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbra Streisand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mutterings: "Who's she?" "Yeah, her..." But Danny says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissinger...Dershowitz...Roseanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And Larry King...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he Jewish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Leona Helmsley, Michael Eisner, Bob Dylan, Phillip Roth, Ruth Bader Ginsberg, Steven Spielberg, Winona Ryder, Beverly Sills, Alvin Toffler, Katherine Graham. All of them. But not yet. We don't want celebrity obscuring the issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, no one will know why the victims are being killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't announce it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say nothing. After two or three, people will try to find a pattern. A reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when it comes out, the public will be outraged. It will look like Germany all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that what we want? Germany all over again? Only done right this time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd feels a deep atavistic thrill. Zampf glances at Mrs. Moebius....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without speeches or political parties. A movement without leaders so that no one can stop it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is stunned to silence. Mrs. Moebius signals Curt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's break this up for now.... (to Danny) Could you wait a minute...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny -- flushed with triumph -- stands looking down at t city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACROSS THE ROOM -- MRS. MOEBIUS & CURTIS ZAMPF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) ...I thought we agreed, no anti- Semitism...it's exactly what we're trying to put behind us.... Trash the blacks, fine; but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see how they reacted to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. But that only plays in this room, with people who aren't embarrassed to call themselves Nazis. If you want a modern fascism, you don't mention Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a romantic movement, Curtis. It always has been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lina, the Thousand-Year Reich barely lasted a decade.... Do you really want to go down that road again? In America of all places, where obedience and discipline are not exactly the national virtues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks over at Danny, now chatting with Carla....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks well. But what do we do with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's find out who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean who he really is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DANNY & CARLA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not in school? What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work at the Big Boy warehouse. In Queens. I drive a fork-lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you read all that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just read it....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. She's beckoning to him. He gives Carla a look, then crosses to her, sitting in a chair she indicates. Curtis offers him a drink; he declines. Carla takes one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lina Moebius. And you are...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Balint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Balint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What part of Germany are you people from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the Rhineland originally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you with the FBI, Mr. Balint?... Or any other law enforcement agency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to ask you the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiles, laughter. Everyone seems to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you really after, Daniel?... Do you just want to kill Jews, or do you have something larger in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla watches, silent. Danny is aware of both mother and daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without blood -- a willingness to spill it -- there's no real power, no authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased by this) Curtis is afraid you'll marginalize us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're already marginal. We are saying what no one else has the guts to say. Isn't that precisely our appeal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what Jew would you kill first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilio Manzetti...former ambassador to France. Managing partner at Damon, Schwarzchild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lina, explaining) An investment banking house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's Jewish? Manzetti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally. The family emigrated from Bulgaria when he was eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have to research it, study his routines, his security.... But ideally on a New York street at midday, using a small-caliber automatic without a silencer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why no silencer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want it to be an event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lina stands, takes a sherry. Everyone else rises with her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, why don't you come visit us in the country. We have young men with lots of energy and no ideas. Maybe you could give them something to think about.... Bring your friends, if you like....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Curtis leads him toward the door, Danny looks around f Carla, hears WOMEN'S VOICES arguing in German. Frustrated he goes down the stairs....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and the other skins walking down the middle of the street, drinking beer, oblivious to traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring your friends.... We're not his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I won't bring you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others laugh. Someone HONKS behind them. Billings tur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK YOU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, bonehead...get your moon ass off the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billings turns and throws his beer at the voice. A CRASH, BREAKING GLASS, a screech of BRAKES, CAR DOORS open and s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go back to Rwanda and give each other AIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That does it. The skins run out of frame. SOUNDS of a fig Danny watches, indifferent, then finally joins in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The skins in a cell. O.L., head bloody, moaning and vomit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't see....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carleton comforts him. Billings paces, looks at Danny, sitting against the wall, relaxed for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, do you like it here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read Mein Kampf? Hitler had all his best ideas in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Balint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny looks up: a JAILER unlocks the cell. Carla appears behind him. Danny stops without stepping through the open

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other skins are surprised, moved. Carla and Danny sta at each other. Finally she turns to the jailer....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I use a credit card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mercedes pulls up, Carla driving. The skins climb out, Carleton guiding O.L., who cannot see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should go to a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billings turns back, sees Danny still in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at Carla, stays in the car) We'll go to the country sometime, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billings nods grudgingly. The car drives off. Carleton gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Danny, man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla leads Danny through the darkened apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old bookcase full of leather-bound German volumes...Da opens one marked Hofmannsthal. He tries to read a marked passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...und die Worte zerfielen mir im Munde wie modrige Pilze..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And the words fell apart in my mouth like moldering mushrooms..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come so many of the books are in Spanish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're my father's. He's from Argentina. My mother's family went there during the war. That's where they met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they still together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in a mental institution.... He's been there for ten years, off and on. Mostly on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a Nazi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess. His parents are. He doesn't care about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he care about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killing himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other. There's that gulf between them t they have to cross, but they're not sure how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think people ever commit suicide out of happiness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's stupid. Why would they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs. She takes his hand, rubs the bruised knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not like the others, are you?... Your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. Basically I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans close, whispers....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's surprised, but not very. He grabs her wrist, twists

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! That's too hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her out of frame. She starts to say something, b it's cut off by another CRY OF PAIN. We keep looking out window....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light has shifted across the city, and we hear only a muffled sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA TURNS to look at...Carla and Danny naked on th bed. He lies back, reading the German book. She's curled her side, weeping abjectly. Still sobbing, she rolls over buries her face in his chest. We see that his neck is scratched up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it again....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to fondle him. He ignores it until he finishes the poem, then turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light has shifted again. Danny sleeps alone, his face strangely innocent. Carla drops onto the bed, shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up...you gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens his eyes. She's dressed, her hair wet from the shower, a faint puffiness around her mouth. He pulls her down to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you have to leave. I've got to write a paper. (slaps his stomach hard) Out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up. Her face is cold, indifferent. He gets to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny on his way to the door, hears something, turns...CU ZAMPF is coming out of a bedroom in his underwear. From within...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring the paper, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis now sees Danny. A look between them. Danny goes ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once a Jewish neighborhood, now occupied chiefly by black Latins and more recent immigrants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Danny (wearing headphones) comes down the steps... TWO BLACK KIDS (big, menacing, boombox) are coming up, blocki his way. Danny walks right between them, forcing them apa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn, glare after him. He turns, glares back. They scoff and keep going up. He walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets himself into a row house. We barely notice the mezzuzah on the door post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nearly vanished world of lower-middle-class Jewish life though the "Jewishness" (menorah, kiddush cup...) is restricted to one dusty corner behind a secular chaos of books, newspapers, half-empty cups, half-filled glasses..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's FATHER, 55, sits on a faded chair, an oxygen mask a cart beside him. Danny's sister, LINDA, 30, is cutting hair with a scissors. When Danny enters, they both look u at him in surprise, alarm, possibly even love. For a mome no one knows what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father begins to wheeze, puts the mask over his face breathes deeply. Linda tells him to lean back; resumes cutting. On the wall we see Danny's BAR MITZVAH PHOTO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Danny has found a stack of mail, all addressed him. His father and sister are visible behind him in a mirror. Without speaking, he goes down the hall, and we h him DESCEND STAIRS to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny has taken off his coat (revealing a black T-shirt w a red swastika), and is going through a number of cardboa boxes marked "D," pulling out comic books, baseball glove martial arts gear, drawings of voluptuous women, morbid gothic figures, gun magazines, books about Hitler, Nazis...and finally a .22 AUTOMATIC stuffed in a blue soc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes the clip, checks the slide, while nodding to t MUSIC coming through his earphones. He looks up, sees LIN at the foot of the stairs, pulls off the headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knocked, you didn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late to conceal the gun; he places it beside him She does her best to ignore the swastika shirt....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came to get some stuff. I'll be out in five minutes. (off her) He doesn't want me around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down as if that were not true, or the way in wh it is too complicated to go into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to die. (as Danny looks away) He won't take his medicine. He eats dairy. He probably still smokes when I'm not around. (off Danny's helpless gesture) I asked him to come live with us. Alex offered to share his room, unsolicited.... But he didn't want to be any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he couldn't be bitter about living alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why deprive him of his greatest pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exchange what are almost smiles. But then the subjec she's been trying to avoid -- the only subject -- suddenl erupts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Jesus Christ, Danny, how can you wear that thing?... You know what it means? To your people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not my people....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell it to Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he decides? Hitler's the chief rabbi now?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this because of those kids who used to beat you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kids?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Polacks? From Sacred Heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody ever beat me up. (as she sighs, turns to go) Look, Linda, there're fifty reasons. Even if you knew them all, there'd be another fifty you didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know them? (off him) I made him some noodles for dinner. You can heat them up and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get back to the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can heat them up and eat with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny (now wearing a plain white T-shirt) bends over the coffee table eating a noodle casserole and reading the Po His father eats off a TV table. He finishes, cursorily wi his mouth, picks up a remote and turns on the television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Friday....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hoarse rasp) Do I give a shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny holds up both hands: he's not arguing, simply infor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Torah says not to light a fire on the Sabbath, because it's work, correct? (Danny sighs) But if alternating current's running through the wires every second of every day, and I throw a switch, send it here instead of there, how is that lighting a fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Do chickens give milk?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He channel-surfs until he comes to a stand-up COMIC doing routine. They both watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV: the COMIC is funny in a brutal, compulsive way. Lots pop references, implicit postmodern nihilism. The routine reflects what Danny (and the Shiites, the Unabomber, Timo McVeigh, T.S. Eliot, et al.) have against the modern worl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis Leary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father grunts with grim satisfaction, he suspected as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering consolation) Howard Stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sighs: why bother. But adds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam Sandler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like Mr. Dorfmann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they watch, apropos of nothing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After your mother died, that's when you stopped going to shul. Doing your homework. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's when the Mets started to stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause they got rid of Johnson. He knew how to deal with the assholes. Dallas Green, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valentine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father snorts. On TV the comic gets off a line, and t both laugh. Their laughs are quite similar; they glance a each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some maple walnut in the freezer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda says you're not supposed to have dairy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little... What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny goes into the kitchen. The father extracts a pack o Salems from between the cushions, lights one, takes a desperate drag... The phone RINGS. He curses, stubs it ou grabs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?... Hold on.... It's for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny gives his father a dish of ice cream, takes the pho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Balint? My name's Guy Danielsen. I'm a reporter with the New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed, suspicious) New York Times...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His father looks up. Danny takes the phone into the kitch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing a piece on right-wing groups, post Oklahoma City. I hear you're an important figure in those circles. You have a lot of interesting ideas....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's...yeah, it's true, but... how'd you get this number?... No, not here... Maybe Sunday? There's a place off Queens Blvd. Near the courthouse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HIGH-ANGLE view of the coffee shop. After a moment, Dan enters frame, starts toward it....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny enters, looks around. To his surprise he sees GUY DANIELSEN from the Nazi meeting rising, extending his han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny...Guy Danielsen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonic, now he gets it) You...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy shrugs, smiles apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE -- DANNY & GUY WITH COFFEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Danny declines, Guy gets out a small cassette recorder is about to turn it on, when he notices Danny's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it okay if I record this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... Yeah, fine, go ahead... So what's this about? Is this about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to figure out where the radical right is going to next....I thought you were the most interesting person at that meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Curtis Zampf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis is a politician -- and a bit of a hustler. He's not a thinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other night you said the modern world is a Jewish disease. Could you elaborate on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the movement -- the racialist movement -- we believe there's a hierarchy of the races. Not just in IQ, but in the civilization, the art, the forms of government, the civilizations that each race produces... Why are you writing this down if you're recording it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It helps me concentrate.... So does that mean you're a white supremacist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I be, a white inferior- ist? A multicultural Zulu egalitarian? Let me ask, where are your people from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother's family is French, my father's was German, originally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German. Mine, too. So who do you think's given more to the world, the Germans -- Beethoven, Goethe, Nietzsche -- or the entire continent of Africa? Ibos, Bantus, Mandingos...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, what about the Jews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny shifts in his seat, growing more interested....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jews are different.... Blacks are disgusting and inferior, but it's like criticizing a retarded child. The Jews are...a poison in the human well....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poison...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me give you an example.... Sexuality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sexuality??? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever fuck a Jewish girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What                        ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever fuck one, Guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing, embarrassed) What's that go to do with...I've gone out with a, with Jewish women. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And? WHat did you notice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice? Like what...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewish girls like to give head, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Jewish men like to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody likes to, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's very pleasurable. But the Jews are obsessed with it. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the Jew is essentially female.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Female...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real men -- white, Christian men -- we fuck a woman. We make her come with our cocks. But the Jew doesn't like to penetrate and thrust -- he can't assert himself that directly -- so he resorts to perversions. Oral sex is technically a perversion, you know that, don't you? (as Guy nods) After a woman has been with a Jewish man, she never wants a normal partner again. A normal man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean the Jew is the better lover?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not listening. He isn't better. He gives pleasure, but that's actually a weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, what makes you think you know all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say I've done due diligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, fine, it's not that the Jew, the Jews own the media and the banks. It's that they're sexually corrupt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jews clearly control the media and the banks. Investment banks, not the commercial ones. But the point is they carry out in those realms the same principles they display in sexuality. They undermine traditional life; they deracinate society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny leans over to make sure Guy's getting it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deracinate... Tear out the roots. A people -- a real people -- derives its genius from the land: the sun, the sea, the soil. This is how they know themselves. But the Jew doesn't have soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has Israel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those aren't Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they're Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notice the Israelis: a fundamentally secular society. They no longer need Judaism because they have soil. The real Jew is a wanderer, a nomad. He has no roots, no attachments. So he "universalizes" everything. He can't hammer a nail, plow a field. He can only buy and sell, invest capital, manipulate markets. He takes the life of a people rooted in soil and turns it into a cosmopolitan culture based on books, ideas, numbers. This is his strength.... (pumped; this is what he loves) Take the great Jewish minds: Marx, Freud, Einstein. What have they given us: communism, infantile sexuality and the atom bomb. In a mere three centuries since these guys emerged from the ghettos of Europe, they've taken us from a world built on order and reason and hurled us into a chaos of class warfare, irrational urges and relativity, a world where the very existence of matter and meaning is in doubt. Why? Because it is the deepest impulse of the Jewish soul to unravel the very fabric of life until nothing is left but thread, nothing but nothingness. Nothingness without end...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are all Jews the same?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Differences exist, of course, but they're irrelevant. For the Jew, his Jewishness dominates everything. Even the ones who renounce it, who hate it, who want to cut it out of their hearts a knife...can't escape. They're still just Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy finishes writing that and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, this is great. You're incredibly articulate. One more thing... How can you believe this when you're a Jew yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Danny smiles at the mistake....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Excuse me?... (Guy says nothing) You're kidding, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Rabbi Stanley Nadelman? He used to be at Congregation Beth Elohim in Ozone Park...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? How would I know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says you were bar mitzvahed there, in March 1988.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that? And you call yourself a reporter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying it's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me.  DO I look Jewish?  Look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates his hair, turns sideways to show his profile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you ever bar mitzvahed anywhere else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who you're fucking with here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to find out, Danny. Who am I fucking with here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sputtering, unsure what to say) Listen to me....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would Nadelman lie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To discredit me. Because I know who they are. Look, I thought I explained it to you. Those people can say or do anything. And they will. It's all narrative to them, it's... Are you going to print what this guy said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a reason not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's slander. It's reckless disregard. I'll sue you and your fucking Jew paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean you deny what he says is true? Yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUN: pulled from Danny's pants, slammed down on the table Guy sits back abruptly. Danny picks it up, cocks it....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. Look at me, Guy.... Oh, now you can't look at me? Look at me, you schmuck. Look at me.... (pokes the gun in Guy's face) You print that shit in the New York Times...I'll kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the place is staring. Danny walks out, stuffi the gun in his pants, shoving a man aside to get to the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traveling through low, tree-covered mountains listening t the overture to Tannhuser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carleton driving; O.L. (one eye bandaged) riding shotgun. back: Billings and Danny (flipping through a Times.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have to listen to this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd we have to leave so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody made you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's running from the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.L., how come your mother gives you a car when you're too fucking blind to drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cackling) She says 'cause now I can't crack it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, O.L., assholes at four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.L. leans out the window, giving dual "birds" to an empt street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK YOU, ASSHOLES. SUCK MY DICK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van stopped in front. All of them out of the car. No one's around except the noisy CRICKETS. The city kids are uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought there were people here....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go look....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks toward the back. Billings decides to go with him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better stay with the van....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you better stay here and guard it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.L. gives him the finger. Carleton laughs -- but he stay back, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Billings see PEOPLE in back. Now NINE YOUNG MEN and a bulldog come to greet them: survivalists, speed-fre skinheads...and one blank loner (DRAKE) with a blue swast tattooed to his lips like a tiny kiss. A case of STEROID EXCESS fixes his gaze on Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're from New York. Curtis Zampf invited us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?... Curtis who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they in the wrong place? Then someone laughs, they al relax, exchange greetings, obscure handshakes. Everyone's just getting comfortable when, for no apparent reason...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: slugs Danny in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stumbles backward. The others crowd around, keep him f falling, also from getting away. Billings starts to help, but people grab him: this is Danny's problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steroid comes at him.... Danny steps inside the charge an goes to work on the bigger man's body. We barely see what happens, but we hear it and feel the crowd's shock. Danny stronger than we realized and much more vicious. In secon Steroid sinks to his knees, face bloody. Danny holds up h leans close:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steroid mumbles in the affirmative. Danny nods -- then hi him four more shots to the face. Even this crowd winces. Steroid drops with a wet thud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Danny straightens up, wiping the blood off his hands, people instinctively step back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which was his room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ferrety, glasses) Number ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the end: has an extra window. Danny walks into the roo Steroid's stuff starts flying out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny on a pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm trying to reach Carla, is she?... Did she get my other message?... No, I'll call back....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny hangs up the phone, glances into a room where we di glimpse Nazis taking drugs, drinking beer, screaming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking niggers... Fucking niggers? Fucking gooks!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then incomprehensible shrieking rage, a fight, breaking g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sighs, bored. He spots two nerdy Nazis, KYLE and WH playing some battle re-creation board game and rehashing WWII....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Look, if Hitler had knocked out the RAF in '39, which he could easily, easily have done, he'd have taken England, and the U.S. wouldn't have had --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A staging ground for the invasion, yeah. But he blew it going after civilian targets. Just like he blew the Russian front, diverting supplies to Auschwitz....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny looks up the hill toward a farmhouse perched above them. One light burns inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mrs. Moebius?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her place is down the road. But she just comes out for weekends sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny squats to look at the board game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Stalingrad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettysburg. But we're refighting it with World War I technology. It's a fucking bloodbath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grins maniacally. Danny smiles. Kyle is emboldened by Danny's unexpected friendliness, lowers his voice....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was unbelievable what you did to Lucas. The guy's an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look right through him. He's there, but there's something on the other side of him that you want. It's all you want. And whatever's in the way doesn't matter.... Then it's easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kyle and Whit contemplate his wisdom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either of you know anything about explosives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look up, very interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jews: MAN (black hat, beard), WOMAN (sheitl, shawl), BOY (kippah, twerpy), GIRL (fat, ugly), even a DOG, a Star of David on its side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blacks: MAN (watermelon, pitchfork), WOMAN (fat, fried chicken), BOY (syringe, 9mm), GIRL (twins, welfare check) DOG (black).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a breath, let out a little, relax, then squeeze. (a RIFLE SHOT; nothing's hit) Again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another SHOT. A bullet hits the Jewish boy in the rear en Sunlight streams through the hole. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny peers down the barrel of an M-16. Kyle squats besid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one were you aiming at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle nods, patient, is drawing Danny's attention back to target when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sets up beside them, begins squeezing off rounds so fast, sounds like an automatic weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TARGETS: the bullets chew up and knock over all four Jews And selectively: shooting the man's face, the woman's breasts, the boy and girl in the groin. The dog he merely flattens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drake looks at Danny without expression, drops the clip, shoves in a fresh one and riddles the black family in similar fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, pay phone to his ear, flipping through a New York Times. He throws it aside as a voice comes on the line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla?... It's me, Danny...Danny Balint...? We met at that...[meeting at your house.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember.... Kill any Jews yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't realize you cared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. I was just curious how full of shit you were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that there was a New York Times reporter there that night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, which one? I bet it was the guy with the Prada shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't notice his shoes.... Did your mother know he was there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it. How did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called me up. He wanted to talk to me about my ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet. He didn't realize that nobody who talks such a good game ever plays one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't complaining about my play last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a much easier game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come visit, we'll have a rematch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too many good players down here. I'm with one right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigger and better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how come you're talking to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click. She's gone. He hangs up, walks straight into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nazis sprawled about, drinking beer, impassively watching The bulldog pants on the floor. Carleton calls to it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas Chamber...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It trots over, receives a scrap of food. Everything desul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the whole room) When are we going to do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People glance up wearily: give us a break....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, Billings, O.L., and Drake walk through the town, looking for trouble. A couple of local TEENAGERS watch th impressed by the swastikas, tattoos, swagger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two WAITERS (Jewish college students, athletic, confident watch the Nazis come in. One indicates to the other that he'll handle this. He brings menus, water; he's carefully polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sure do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Waiter ignores the innuendo, readies his order pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ham and cheese on white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forbearance) We don't have ham. We don't have cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what the menus are for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles. Billings glares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roast beef and Swiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said: no cheese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with cheese?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a kosher restaurant. We don't serve meat with dairy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bible only says don't seethe a kid in its mother's milk. But chickens don't give milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you want cheese, go someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's stupid, right? You admit it's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't admit it's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have chicken with eggs but not with milk. Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here to talk about religious law, if you don't like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you already talked about it: you said it's not stupid. Why isn't it stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling the other Waiter) Steve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's going to explain it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve approaches, a sawed-off broom handle over his shoul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a problem here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sure fucking do. We don't understand why you can't eat chicken with milk. It doesn't make sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an intellectual) Religion isn't about making sense. It's about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about the incomprehensible, Steve, not the idiotic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That explains it! Now we understand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazis laugh. Steve swings the broom handle at Danny.. ducks it, grabs it, slams it back at him.... GAVEL RAPS..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A JUDGE (white-haired, red-faced, blue-eyed, well-meaning peers down at the four NAZIS, still bruised from the figh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...As the altercation appears to have been instigated equally on both sides, prison terms strike the court as excessive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazis are relieved. Spectators disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, the defendants' political views suggest that they might profit from contact with members of our community whose experiences differ from their own....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUMBERS TATTOOED ON AN ARM...a thumb steadily smooths the skin as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Rumanian accent, uninflected) ...When I refused to have sex with him, the warden had my sister, Esther, executed in front of the entire block....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazis, accompanied by a "HATE COUNSELOR" (male) sit i plastic chairs opposite five elderly JEWS. The speaker is her late 60s, still something of a beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Everyone considered it my fault. After that, of course, I did anything he wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he just rape you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNICKERING among the Nazis, a whispered crack:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd want to fuck her anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear one more remark like that, we go back to the court for resentencing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a pig, like you, so perhaps he had no taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazis laugh. The Jews try to calm the woman, though s has spoken without any evident emotion. Billings gets up restless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, please. (as Billings sits) Thank you, Mrs. Cohen. Mr Liebowitz, you indicated you had a story you wanted to tell....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nazis are dozing, staring out the window. O.L. threads a piece of dental floss through the zipper pull on his trousers. Danny is visibly disgusted by the whole busines Over this we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The man was afraid to let us hide on his farm any longer, but he agreed to take us to a more remote place. On the way he was stopped at a checkpoint, and when the soldiers found us in the hay, one of them grabbed my son out of my arms. He began to cry, so I reached for him, not to take him back, simply...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MAN: mid-70s, tall, stooped, a crushed spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...simply to assure him I was there. But the sergeant became enraged.... He stuck his bayonet in my son's chest, and lifted him up, impaled on it. My son was three years old....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billings is muttering, "What a load of crap..." The Hate Counselor looks over sharply. The other Nazis are stunned the story. Danny can barely contain himself, though we ar not sure why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He held him up so that the blood spurting out of him feel on my face.... The soldiers were laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse hitched to a hay wagon; FARMER driving. THREE NAZ SOLDIERS have discovered a Jewish family hiding in the ha A sergeant is holding up something unseen on the end of h rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Polish man who has been telling the story looks up at whatever it is. Blood falls on him. The Nazis are laughin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the blood stopped, the sergeant pushed my son off the bayonet and said, "There, you can have him now...."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is silent. The Nazis faces blank, shaken. Until.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do while the sergeant was killing your son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, Danny, it's all bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Billings) Shut up. (to man, mid-70s) What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could he have done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could he have done?? You fucking kikes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't say that....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazi's killing his kid. He could've jumped the guy. He could've gouged his eyes out, grabbed the bayonet and gutted him.... What would you have done if they were killing your son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The counselor is briefly confused....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUMANIAN WOMAN & OTHERS ...They'd have shot him on the spot.... He would have been dead in two seconds.... Who are you judge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SO THEY SHOT HIM! SO HE WAS DEAD. SO WHAT. HE'S WORSE THAN DEAD NOW. HE'S A PIECE OF SHIT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's it. You're going back to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over him, to Polish man) What do you think you should have done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, you think you know what you would have done? You have no idea. You can't even imagine what that was like. And you never will....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't listen to them, Danny. It's all a bunch of crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is crap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The so-called Holocaust. It never happened. It's the hoax of the twentieth century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted with this idiocy) Oh, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, it's true. There were no six million. At most, two hundred thousand Jews died in the camps. And the majority of them were from disease and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jews are shouting about historical records, the disappearance of families, whole towns.... But Danny is l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you read this? Robert Faurisson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised he knew) Yeah. He's a respected scholar. Even No-am Chomsky says he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billings, if Hitler didn't kill six million, why is he your hero?... Concentration camps all over Europe, and he only gets rid of a measly two hundred thousand.... He's a putz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some surprise that a Nazi is arguing against a denier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler was not a putz. Hitler was real. God created him to punish the Jews for abandoning God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other survivors are embarrassed by this, but the Anci Jew ignores them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is you who are putzes. Little pishas with your dreams of hatred and killing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny scoffs, gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We have nothing to learn from these people. They should learn from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Danny walks out, the Ancient Jew catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what should we learn from you, Daniel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her use of Danny's name feels knowing, slyly invasive. Al SOUND VANISHES for a beat, and Danny barely manages to sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill your enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle opens the trunk of his car, shows Danny inside: two bags of shotgun powder and several lengths of metal pipin with screw-on caps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green dot -- shotgun powder. For pipe bombs. (off Danny's reaction, smiles) A guy in a lumberyard gave it to me. A donation to the cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Danny.... Guess who's here.... (as Danny quickly slams the trunk) Your girlfriend... She's up at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the driveway: Carla's Mercedes, a Triumph motorcycle. Danny peers in through the windows, goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sees Carla sitting on a green sofa wearing a white sundress and leafing through a magazine. Curtis is mixing drinks. Lina is practicing with her stylus on a new electronic organizer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My L's keep coming out as C's....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spots Danny) The prisoner returns....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny greets them all. Carla barely looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, get a drink and come talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny talking with Lina and Curtis but watching Carla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Insulting people who were in the camps. ...What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're liars and cowards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they are. But what do we accomplish by pointing it out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the truth....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis rolls his eyes. Lina signals him to lay off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, what do you think of our troops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be diplomatic) They have guts. And they know what they hate...which is good. But they have no idea why; they don't think, they don't read.... They're on beer and crank half the time....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone RINGS in another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young people in this country... They're like pigs; all they want is happiness.... But one needs pigs sometimes. (as it RINGS again; to Carla) Liebchen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla puts down her magazine, goes out to the kitchen. Danny's eyes follow her, and Curtis's follow his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel you're making progress here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Ilio Manzetti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget Manzetti.... Take on something simple. Something you can actually accomplish. (to Curtis) Maybe he'd be more valuable in the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An urban type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is stung. Carla calls from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny...telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts: who could be calling him here? As he goes into the kitchen to take the phone, Curtis says quietly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's mad, Lina, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hears him but doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny picks up the phone; there's a New York Times beside Carla busies herself about the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what today is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda... How did you get this number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mom's yartzeit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny starts to hang up, sees Carla watching, turns away keeping his voice low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get the fucking number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to say kaddish for her. It's the only thing she asked from us....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do it on the inside....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me what I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I want you to do it on the outside, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. He grabs the Times, looks through it quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Linda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping the Times) Why won't you talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking to you right now. Who's Linda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to kiss her. She pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can I see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) Carla, it's time to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go visit my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's at a home out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to walk past. He grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm coming to your room tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to pull free; he won't let her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
