dialogues.text: Just after midnight. Five past... But don't come through the house, they'll hear you. I'm in the back bedroom, second floor. Climb onto the kitchen roof, I'll leave the window open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to kiss her, but she ducks away and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is parked opposite a fortresslike building of soile brick. For a long time he cannot bring himself to get out Finally he opens the door....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LARGE WOMAN, about 40, her body barely contained by a brilliant magenta dress, greets him with a smile the size a wedding cake. She holds out a prayer book stuffed with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shabbat shalom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She speaks quietly, not wanting to disturb the service, y even so her voice is huge, and her flashing eyes clearly expect some kind of enthusiastic response. Within we hear the ALENU being chanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny ignores her and the proffered siddur. A basket of yarmulkes seems to infuriate him, but he snatches one any and, conveying a helpless disgust, puts it on his head. F within he hears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in rough unison) Ba-yom, ha-hoo, ba-yom, ha hoo...(etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands with his hand on the door, but not opening it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On that day, the Eternal shall be One. And His Name shall be One....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The organist plays a brief decrescendo....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mourner's kaddish can be found on page 187....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's startled but not intimidated, is about to respond, when Danny simply turns and walks out of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops beneath an open window through which he hears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Grant us peace, thy most precious gift, O Thou Eternal source of peace. We recall with loving memory those whom Thou hast summoned unto thee. And we mention by name...Sophie Budnitz...Bernard Schwabb...Milton Lifter...Aaron Lustig...Minnie Baum...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny closes his eyes, but at the end adds, under her bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Harriet Kantor Balint...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half dozen VOICES, including Danny's, recite in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY & OTHERS Yis-ga-dal v'yis-ka-dash sh'may ra-bo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body of the congregation joins in on certain phrases, producing a subtle and solemn music. Danny chants the ent prayer, and the moment it ends, and the rabbi begins the benediction....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May the Lord bless you and keep you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he starts toward his car. But the Rabbi's VOICE seems follow him, unnaturally loud and clear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May He cause the light of His countenance to shine upon you and be gracious unto you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Eat shit....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...May you be blessed in your going forth as you were in your coming....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to the empty street) EAT SHIT, ASSHOLES....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And let us say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RABBI & CONGREGATION (with organ; singsong) Ah -- ah -- ah....men....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Danny reaches the van, he sees the LARGE WOMAN silhoue in the open doorway....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOU EAT SHIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny realizes he's still wearing the kippah. He throws i at her, but it only goes a couple of feet. He catches it, throws harder. This time it floats back toward him, and h has to jump out the way to keep it from hitting him. He g in the car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WRISTWATCH: 12:05. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny hoists himself onto the kitchen roof. Above him is open window, candlelight flickering. He starts into the r stops....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla sits on the bed, straddling Curtis, who lies beneat her. She is looking right at Danny. Curtis, unaware of hi keeps thrusting into her from below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny starts to leave, but on second thought stays. Carla stares expressionless, yet more attentive to him than to Curtis. Indeed, their eyes never leave each other, so tha when she becomes aroused, we understand that it is Danny is responding to, Danny she is really making love to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gradually her face loses its aloofness and seems to reach out to him, to reveal feelings that she can no longer den She holds her gaze until, at the final instant, she shudd out a series of stifled cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she looks again, the window is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny reading. A KNOCK at the door. He looks up, Curtis comes in. Danny stiffens at the sight of him, but Curtis friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny tilts the book to show him: History of Political Philosophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Strauss... (nods approvingly) I've got to go to Boston. I came to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Mrs. Moebius and...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They left an hour ago. (off Danny's disappointment) You mind some personal advice? Forget Carla. That's not the side your bread's buttered on. (off Danny's silence) How soon can you get back to the city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week or so. There's something I want to do here first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? (off Danny's silence) Okay. Surprise us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of SPLITTING WOOD. Then VOICES in a cavernous s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow, shit... You're stepping on my fucking -- ...Get off me...Goddammit... (sounds of PUNCHES, a SCUFFLE) Stop it!... Where's the light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One appears, illuminating nothing, dissipating into the still vaster darkness. A SERIES OF LIGHTS bang on in ecclesiastical bursts, illuminating: a vaulted ceiling... stained glass panels... We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dour, ornate place built in the early decades of the century. The sight of it silences everyone for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jew World...!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drake, Billings, Carleton, O.L. and Steroid run wild... kicking over benches...spray-painting swastikas...hurling prayer books...urinating from the balcony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Danny looks around like someone revisiting his childho home: slides his hand along a pew back...leafs through a chumash...gazes up at the eternal lamp behind its red glass...the gilded doors of the ark... A hint of Kol Nidr MUSIC haunts him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself, barely a whisper) Shut up. Fuck you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny turns; Kyle is right behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Where is it? (as Kyle hoists a sports bag) Okay, let's take one of these panels off so we can get under the bema...the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they unscrew a panel, Carleton runs past. A football flashes overhead. We hear GLASS BREAK...LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY WATCHES KYLE attach a bomb (four sticks of dynamite wired to a digital timer) to a 2x4 with a bungee cord. He hooks the ends, cautiously lets go. The cord springs free The bomb falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle gasps. Danny catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frozen, they look at each other. Kyle exhales, takes the bomb and, with Danny holding it, carefully restrings the bungee. A MECHANICAL NOISE overhead:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, look at this shit....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle has no idea and doesn't care. Danny scrambles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straightening up, Danny is stunned by a vision:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...their silver crowns and breastplates, velvet robes. An Steroid Excess, lifting one out. Danny reacts with an instinctive horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Put that down! ...Put it back in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steroid -- cowed by Danny -- starts to obey, but before h can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaults onto the stage) Let's look at the fucking thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each CURSE makes Danny wince, but he just hovers about nervously as Billings and Steroid try to unwrap the Torah while others gather, some comically wrapping themselves i tallises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it there, on the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates the bema, stepping back as if to deny any involvement, yet at the same time trying to monitor everything they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating crowns, the yod...) Just be careful with the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puts a crown on his head) "If I were king of the forest...not Prince, not Duke, not Earl..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny cannot endure this desecration, but everyone else laughs, so he keeps his mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impulsively taking over) Here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves his way in and, gripping the handles, unrolls t Torah. Low MURMURS at the sight of the broad columns, the mysterious calligraphy, the CRACKLING parchment. Danny himself is struck by the sudden immediacy of the sacred t OVER this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooo... Weird... You read it from right to left.... The letters look like squashed bugs.... What kind of paper is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not paper, it's parchment. It's made from sheepskin. And all the letters are drawn by hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neat calligraphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny nods, then, as if against his will....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called the flame alphabet. It's supposed to be the word of God written in fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mystics tried to read the white spaces around the letters. They thought there was a whole alternative language hidden there, with secret, alternative meanings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny sees Drake watching him, smirks to express his disg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you know all this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you don't know it? (pressing the advantage) How can you say you hate the Jews when you don't know anything about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. I hate the Jews at least as much as you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't.... If you hated them, you'd study them, so you'd know why you hate them. You know what tefillin is? Tsitsis? Shotness? You know the kaddish from the kiddush? (obviously not) Eichmann? He went to Israel. He studied the Torah, the Talmud, the Mishnah, the whole bit. He hated Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Eichmann?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Eichmann?!!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's incredulous, though it's not clear how many of th others know why Eichmann was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was head of the Gestapo's Jewish sector. He deported people to the camps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching toward the parchment) Can we touch it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but not on the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the fuck not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warning finger) Just don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billings bristles at Danny's authority; Carleton says to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you see Raiders of the Lost Ark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was an ark, man. That was a Torah. They fucked around with it, and the Torah melted their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a movie, you moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, go ahead. Touch the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others are gathered around, delicately touching the sheepskin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes through, looks at the Torah. He runs his finger over the crinkled parchment, the smooth black letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said not on the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Billings grabs the parchment in both hands and tries to tear it. It's tougher than it looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to stop him, but -- accidentally or not -- Drake gets in the way, and before Danny can do anything else, Billings crumples it and finally tears a long gash into t scroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This produces a strange effect on the others. Some (Kyle, Steroid, Drake) join in. They knock the aitz off the bema it rolls out, exposing ten feet of Torah. They stamp on i spit on it.... Others (Carleton, O.L.), though less troub than Danny, are surprised (and embarrassed) by their own revulsion at these acts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny watches helplessly, like the survivor who did nothi as his son was murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally the Torah lies torn and soiled on the stage. A strange silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Danny kneels by the Torah. With a tallis, he attempts clean the parchment. Carleton and O.L. help him roll it o the aitz. [Echo "Christ taken down from cross" with Torah Christ.] They replace the cover, the yod, the crowns....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Danny lifts it up, holds it to him as if it were dead child. He closes his eyes, murmurs to himself....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shema yisrael adonai elohenu adonai echod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Let's go....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to walk out, carrying the Torah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you taking that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stealing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tragedy was barely averted today at Temple Ahavat Torah when a bomb planted under the bema failed to detonate....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Authorities say that if it had, injuries and loss of life could have been in the dozens....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, Kyle and others watching the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Channel 8's Cindy Pomerantz spoke to Rabbi Malcolm Weiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV: Cindy (sleek, sexy) and the rabbi (handsome, vain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbi, how is it that disaster and tragedy were averted here today at Ahavat Torah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently the power cell in the timer gave out precisely thirteen minutes before the device was set to go off. So we can only conclude that once again God has intervened to save the Jewish people....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving the finger to the TV) Oh, fuck you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know, Cindy, thirteen is a mystical number in the Jewish faith. We believe that God has thirteen attributes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is beside himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Of which the highest is ein sof, which means "without end," or, sometimes, "nothingness without end...."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothingness without end.... That's very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The purest form of spirit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DANNY. Sound fades. He's haunted: "Nothingness without end" was what he'd told Guy Danielsen the Jews were obses with. He seems to hear the cello playing "Kol Nidre" agai Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, everybody out. Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He switches off the TV. Shoves them out the door, slams i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone he sits at the desk, finds himself gazing at the To standing in a corner of his closet, draped in the tallis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the closet door, it bounces open. Slams it again making sure it latches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down, looks at the closed door until, in bitter resignation he gets up and opens it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unrolls the Torah on the bed...Scotch tapes the tear closed...attempts to clean the stain with a moistened clo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is in the bathroom in front of the mirror, holding shirt up with his chin as he wraps the tallis around his torso. When he lowers the shirt, the fringes hang out lik the tsitsis that Orthodox men wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels a weird loathing for this, but he smooths and arranges the tsitsis to look just like a Hasid's. He clic his heels together and gives a Nazi salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alenu l'shab'ach la'adon hacol...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Nazi salute. A KNOCK at the door. He hides the fringes under the shirt, throws a blanket over the Torah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny Balint...Guy Danielsen, New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tucks in the tallis fringes) What do you want? What happened to your article?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't get my editor to run it, but I bet he will now that you've put a bomb in a synagogue. That was you, wasn't it, Danny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny hangs up. Stands there. A VOICE makes him jump....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Danny, want to kill a Jew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny turns: it's Drake. These are the first words he's s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Drake pass a low-slung modern synagogue. A sign announces: AMBASSADOR ILIO MANZETTI Friday, August 31. Da reacts, startled...Drake smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Park up there, we'll walk back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is lit. Within we hear an AMPLIFIED VOICE, presumably Manzetti giving a speech. We can't make out th words. Danny and Drake are hidden among the rhododendrons flanking the parking lot. Danny is watching a door in the side of the building and eating a sandwich as Drake loads scoped rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lie on your stomach and come up on your elbows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to kill a Jew. I already did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny assumes the prone position, Drake sets the rifle in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four. But no one this important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear APPLAUSE within as the speech ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, it's over. He'll take a couple questions, then come out.... Sight down the rifle toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH RIFLE SCOPE: Danny pans from the side door -- whe TWO MEN are smoking -- to a waiting limousine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know they were Jews?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a Jew in a previous life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Danny can respond, Drake gestures toward the synag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny puts his eye back to the scope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOPE POV: stirring at the door. The men put out their cigarettes. Three figures emerge: a MAN and a WOMAN on either side of an older, distinguished-looking man (MANZE They walk this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot him in the head. Always shoot a Jew in the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a bad shot. I don't think I can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get him in the cross-hairs. With those shells, anywhere you hit him, it'll bounce around, rip his insides all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOPE POV: the TRIO walking this way, cross-hairs on Manz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there! Just squeeze he trigger. Slow... Do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny FIRES, misses. Everybody hits the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't. I told you, I can't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny looks over his shoulder. His shirt has ridden up hi back, revealing the tallis wrapped around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drake pulls a .45 from the duffel.... Without thinking, Danny rolls over, fires the rifle. Drake is blown backwar dropping the .45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny leaps up.... Drake's on his hands and knees, his trousers quickly darkening with blood. Danny's upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus...Drake, are you okay...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOOTSTEPS, coming this way. Danny runs. We hear voices, " down.... Stay down.... He's got a gun...." Drake picks himself up, stumbles away, bent over....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny parks the van in an abandoned lot near the river. Quickly wiping down the wheel with his shirt, he tosses o his duffel bag and the scoped rifle. He climbs out, wipes down the door, throws the rifle into the water, grabs the duffel and hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle, it's me Danny. How you doing?... I had to come into the city to see Mrs. MOEBIUS... No, I gave Drake the van, didn't he bring it back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's on the phone, whipping through several newspapers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Since when?... Really? And he didn't call?... No, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds a tiny item: "Gunfire Reported at Synagogue." He scans it: no mention of Drake or himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, come on down.... Can you bring my stuff?... Thanks...and if Drake shows up, let me know right away.... Good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. From behind some books, he extracts the smal caliber handgun he found in his father's house earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny alone, waiting, nervous. He hears FOOTSTEPS approac he touches the gun in the back of his trousers. Lina and Curtis enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How have things been going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (how much do they know?) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates a chair) We want to talk to you about something.... (as they sit, Danny nervous) We're about to launch an aboveground, intellectually serious fascist movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is relieved and intrigued. Lina nods at Curtis to g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to build bridges to certain positions in the political mainstream: works like The Bell Curve, Sociobiology, anti-Zionism, anti- immigration, the com-munitarian issue.... We'll hold conferences: invite liberals, blacks, Jews. Chomsky, Cockburn, Stanley Crouch, Shahack....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been waiting all my life for something like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you to help run it. Give speeches, lead seminars... Handle the fund-raising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapped in the face) Fund-raising??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think you'd be good at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFF-SCREEN we hear the front door. FEET come up the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about...Manzetti, the synagogues....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't seem to be happening, does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been stuck out in the country with those guys who just want to paint swastikas and heil Hitler. How am I supposed to -- (get anything done there?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops short as Carla walks into the room for shopping. She glances at them, puts down her bags, goes into the kitchen....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, the night we met, you said the name Ilio Manzetti. We were impressed. We were excited. But here it is September, and Mr. Manzetti is still walking around breathing the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need intellectuals, we have enough thugs already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's watching Carla go down the hall toward the back, barely bring his attention back to the conversation at ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not an intellectual.... I mean, I read, but... Fund-raising isn't what I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you want to kill Jews on your free time, fine. We need you to raise money. Will you do that for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods but cannot look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dismissed. He rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a suit? (off Danny; to Curtis) Let's get him one.... And a cell phone too. (as Danny turns to go; a joke for her own amusement) And if you insist on blowing up a synagogue, make it that big one on Fifth Avenue, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth Shalom? It's Reform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not that Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what they are. I know those people, and I don't like them. The rest are just a bunch of kikes, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. He manages a smile back and hurries away, fac burning with shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny comes out of the building, squats between two parke cars and vomits, retching spastically until, gasping for breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. Carla walks over to him, wipes his mouth with a crumpled tissue. When she moves to kiss him, he holds bac shy about the smell, but she kisses him anyway, on the mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla, naked, browsing the books, sees something in the closet. It's the Torah Danny took from the synagogue. She unrolls it on the bed, her gaze moving over the mysteriou glossy script. Danny, coming out of the bathroom, sees wh she is doing, and stops short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole it. From a synagogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at the broad printed columns....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come there's no punctuation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a later invention, it's not in the scrolls.... Anyway, the Jews know where the sentences end. They know the whole thing by heart. Every word. Every letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know it like that? By heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can read it, the Hebrew.... Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I want to know.... What is this word? This one here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny looks at the word, then back at her. He's torn betw competing desires, but finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Va-yomer... And he said. (she moves her finger to the left) It goes the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she knew that) Oh, yeah... (moves finger right)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Va-yomer adonai el Avram: lech lecha mayartzcha oo-mimohlad-tcha oo-m'bayt avaycha el ha-ertez asher arecha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And God said to Avram, take yourself away from your land and from the place you were born and from your father's house into the land -- a different land -- and I will show you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny remains silent a moment, affected by the passage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to learn to read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know your enemy.... 'Cause it's a basic text of Western culture. I want to read it in the original. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hebrew's very difficult. It would take years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good at languages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the smooth expanse of her back, the articulat of her spine. He finds her very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put something on. You're not supposed to be naked in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think it's the word of God, and it's holy, and the flesh isn't....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's stupid. (indicating her T-shirt) Put it on, or I won't teach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grudgingly pulls on the shirt as he gets a pencil and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, the Jews love to separate things: the holy from the profane, milk from meat, wool from linen, the Sabbath from the week, the Jew from the gentile.... As if one little scrap of this was going to completely contaminate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't curse in front of it either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs as if indifferent to these rules, yet compelled point them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gets contaminated, the Jews or the gentiles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good question. Both. (draws a letter) Aleph...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks a little like a swastika.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's silent. It holds a place, takes a vowel. The vowels are little dots that go under the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't put them in the Torah. I'll get you a chumash, they'll have them there...Bet...Gimel...Dalid...Hay... (as she repeats the names) How come you're here instead of with Curtis? Besides the Hebrew lessons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sex is better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though his dick is so big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With you there's a tragic dimension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vuv...Zayin...Chet...Tet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He writes each letter as he says it, and she repeats afte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Kyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will be a different kind of device.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That damn thing. You know how it made me look...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Danny. It won't happen again. I'm going to use a brand-new power cell. Plus we'll have a back-up timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta kill some Jews, Kyle. I'm serious. I'm always talking about it. This time it's gotta happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle's confident, and the prospect of this really happeni gives Danny pause. He feels a brief chill, escapes it wit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Drake, did he ever show up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's weird, man. Nobody knows where he went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny nods, gestures for Kyle to split. Kyle looks around walks away. Danny waits a moment, then heads in the oppos direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny walking behind a Hasidic family (MAN, WOMAN, 3-year old BOY, STROLLER)...watching them. At a corner, the fath takes the boy's hand, and as they cross the street, the b glances back at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO NAZI SOLDIERS have just discovered a JEWISH FAMILY hiding in the back of a hay wagon. The POLISH MAN is hold the little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a soldier tries to take the BOY out of his arms, the child panics, clings to his father, screaming, "Papa... Papa..." It is the scene the survivor described in the meeting with the Nazis. But now the father is DANNY'S FATHER....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Hush, come on, don't cry. Everything will be all right....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Nazi sergeant comes over, irritated. The sergeant is Da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German) What's the matter here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Sergeant, in German) Excuse me, I'm sorry, just a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sergeant rips the child out of his arms. The kid beco hysterical. The father manages to take the boy's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Polish) Please, sweetheart, you have to go. I'll see you soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an access of disgust, the sergeant sticks his bayonet into the boy -- or rather, into something offscreen. We h a terrible sound, the child grunts. The family gasps in h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny/sergeant lifts the (unseen) child into the air. Its SHADOW darkens the father's face. Drops of blood run down his cheeks....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny/sergeant stares into the father's face, enraged at man's passivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking kike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY'S FACE -- sweating, haunted, as if he's just woken from the previous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still walking down the street, but now, as if to fle his thoughts, he steps through a door into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Jewish bookstore. He grabs the first book that comes to hand, reads for a moment, throws it down in disgust. Pick it up again, is still reading when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Danny...Danny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at a young man about his own age; wearing a yarmulke, but otherwise normal, hair clean, beard neatly trimmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Stuart. Stuart Schoenbaum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shlomo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny puts down the book, trying to conceal that he's bee reading it. He offers a hand. Stuart manages to restrain impulse to embrace him, but takes the hand warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, it's been since, what, Kenny's wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh... So how are you? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the rabbinic program at JTS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JTS...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you? What are you doing? Something strange, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a kind of...underground...thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed, excited) Are you an artist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... Not that kind of... underground. More a private... business. Private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning he can't talk about it. Stuart nods. Danny notice young woman: dark, curly hair, sharp eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Miriam....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hey, how're you doing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An irony to her. They certainly remember each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at Yale Law -- interning with the district attorney... (Miriam makes a face) We're getting married next spring. In Israel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that's uh...great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at Miriam; but she has picked up the book he'd been reading, is leafing through it. It makes him uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great seeing you....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Danny'd like to come to the minyan for the holidays....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny gives her a dirty look, but Stuart's thrilled:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good idea. We're davening with this group from the seminary. Interesting people, very open-minded, you might like them. And guess who comes...Avi! You guys could go at it again like the good old days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stuart scribbles an address...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Avi used to argue about everything. Torah, Talmud, politics, girls. It always ended in a fistfight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arguments, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands Danny the address) It's a K.I. on 101st. In the little chapel. Try to make it. It'd be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny smiles. He has no intention of going. Once they lea he picks up the book and resumes reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER BRAND, a high-powered CEO, sits behind a big desk, speed-reading something through half-glasses. He finishes removes the glasses. A New York Times is on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You write that? (as Danny nods) Come work for me. You've got a lot to learn; I can teach it to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This? This is a joke. (tossing down the pages) I'll give your group a thousand bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave fifty thousand to that college magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty's an exaggeration. Anyway, that was a different moment. Things were possible that aren't now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I think this moment has possibilities that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I read your piece. It's very smart. And very wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brand's phone beeps, he touches a button, continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the Jewish stuff. It doesn't play anymore. (over Danny's) There's only the market, now, and it doesn't care who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People still need values, beliefs....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they don't. Not the smart ones. (because he likes him) Look, I'll give you five grand if you can document your tax-exempt status.... But when you fall off this horse, come see me. I can show you how to make a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a Jew. Maybe you don't realize it, but you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, uninsulted) Maybe I am. Maybe we're all Jews now. What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Danny, troubled by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-dozen white lumpen sit at desks. Danny writes "ANT SEMITISM" in large letters on a blackboard. He turns....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of you think of yourselves as anti-Semites? (All the hands go up.) Good. Actually, the term is a bit imprecise since technically Jews are only one of the Semitic peoples.... In fact, Arabs are Semites, as are the Eritreans, the Ethiopians, and so on.... But for our purposes an anti- Semite is someone who hates or is against Jews.... Now, why do we hate them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around. The room is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me put it another way. Do we hate them because they push their way in where they don't belong? Or because they're clannish and keep to themselves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmurs of "Yeah. Both." But some are confused by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slightly bigger crowd, a few middle-class-looking people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Because they're tight with money, or because they flash it around? Because they're Bolsheviks or because they're capitalists? Because they have the highest IQs, or because they have the most active sex lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience, confused...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to know the real reason we hate them?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...More people: white collar workers of both sexes, nurse artists. Lapel buttons, bumper stickers, backpacks: "FIGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Because we hate them. (as people exchange puzzled looks) Because they exist. Because it is an axiom of civilization that just as man longs for woman, loves his children and fears death, he hates the Jews. (smiles) There is no reason. If there were, some smart-ass kike would give us an argument, try to prove we were wrong. And of course that would only make us hate them more. In fact we have all the reasons we need in three simple letters: J-E-W. Jew. Say it a million times. It is the only word that never loses its meaning: Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew Jew....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Kyle sitting in the tall grass across the marshlands toward the Manhattan skyline shimmering in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings, looking at watch) "My country 'tis of thee, Sweet land of liberty, Of thee I..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points sharply and an explosion occurs thirty yards aw They run over, pick up the mangled timer. They're pleased

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of stragglers hurry through the door as we hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B'Rosh Hashanah yika-teyvun, uv'yom tsom kippur yey-chateymun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosh Hashanah services. A woman is davening....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it came to pass after these things that God tested Abraham...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY...sitting with Stuart and Miriam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And said to him, "Abraham." And he said, "Here am I..." And God said, "Take your son, your only son, whom you love..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) It's not his only son....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only one he loves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny looks at AVI (athletic, smooth-shaven) who grins sardonically and fakes a punch as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They only kill them when they love them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sliding into a seat next to them) What are you doing here, I thought you were a Nazi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Avi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this guy told me once: Islam and Judaism both start with Abraham murdering his son: first sending Ishmael into the desert, then sacrificing Isaac....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh... Can you please be quiet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Christianity's the same, with minor variations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ridiculous. (to the people around them) Folks, don't listen to this guy. He's a well-known anti-Semite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avi, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching off Danny's hat) ...Look, he's a skinhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a style, Avi.... There are antiracist skins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Believe me, Danny's the racist kind. Are you a fascist, Danny? Yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a fascist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rest my case. He's a Jewish Nazi. He always was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whereas Avi's a Zionist Nazi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Zionists aren't Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're racist, they're militaristic, they act like bullyboys in the territories....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have extermination camps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had Sabra and Shattila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hate them because they're wimps or because they're bullyboys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's startled by the question, but before he can react

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her, to Danny) That was the Lebanese, that wasn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Israeli Army knew about the camps. Sharon encouraged the falangists to go in there and murder all the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that. There's no --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read the early Zionists on European Jewry; they sound like Goebbels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sound like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazis did everything the fhrer told them. You do everything the Torah tells you. Or the rebbe. Identical slave mentality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avi lunges at him. They begin pounding each other. Chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam and Danny walk down West End Avenue together. He's oddly relaxed with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you come tonight? To see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) To hear them read Torah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you hated Torah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean I don't like hearing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point out all the lies and fucked-up thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and even he smiles a little. They walk togethe oddly companionable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the joke: a Jew's shipwrecked on a desert island. When they rescue him, they see he's built two synagogues. They say, for vhat do you need two synagogues? He says, vun to pray in, and vun I'd never set foot in so long as I live, so help me God. (he nods, he's heard it) You pray in the one you'd never set foot in...and vice versa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help what I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops in front of a nice doorman building. He's impre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Lina Moebius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) How did you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work in the DA's office. You go to those meetings, half the people there are informants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the Times guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Times guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the shoes... There was more than one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an excess of paranoia, he walks away. She calls after

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny...Danny... (he doesn't look back) Shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweltering heat. A fan ruffles Carla's hair as she lies o the futon going back and forth between Hebrew/English Tor and a Hebrew grammar. Danny is on the floor lifting weigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, laboriously) Payn tash-chiton v'ashiytem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting her) V'asitem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V'asitem lechem pessel to-monat. And make no graven image of the Lord, or the form of any figure, or of man or woman, or beast or fowl or fish or anything that looks like anything. Because He's not like anything. Not only can't you see Him or hear Him, you can't even think about Him. I mean, what's the difference between that and Him not existing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still exercising) No difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christianity's silly, but at least there's something to believe in. Or not believe. Judaism there's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Nothing but nothingness...Judaism's not about belief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About doing things. You light candles, say prayers, keep the Sabbath, visit the sick....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And belief follows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nothing follows. You don't do it because it's smart or stupid or it saves your soul. You're not saved. Nobody's saved. You do it because the Torah tells you do. You submit to the Torah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't curse in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flips the book closed) Why should I submit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I should just because there's no reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her without answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think you shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judaism doesn't even need God. You have the Torah, the law. That's your fucking God.... (anticipating his objections) The book's closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an access of something, she bites his arm, hard. He winces, pushes her away. She kisses the place she bit. He starts to play with her hair....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're learning the Hebrew really fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I'm good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus you have nothing else to do all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, am I learning it faster than you did? Maybe I'm smarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs, likes her arrogance. But she misunderstands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that funny? You think Jews are the only smart ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they make out, grow aroused...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...? You think I'm Jewish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all you talk about. Jewish, Jewish, Jewish. Nobody talks about it that much except the Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's taken aback by the simple logic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nazis talk about it all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, of course, she has grown up among Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real Nazis. Hitler, Goebbels, they talked about Jews incessantly.... You ever read their diaries?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you became a Nazi? So you could talk about Jews incessantly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, Adolf Hitler couldn't possibly have hated the Jews as much as I do. Not in a billion years. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause he wasn't a rabbi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a punch in the mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... (he doesn't hit her) Why don't we light candles on Friday? Let's light candles.... And say the kaddish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaddish is the prayer for the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean kiddush. Let's say kiddush. And shave my head, fuck through a sheet, all that stuff... (as he walks away) Come on, just for fun. To see what it's like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed with a well-dressed crowd, very different from the crowds we've seen here before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOWN IN FRONT: Mrs. Moebius and Danny talk in low tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the right-wing money in New York is here tonight. They came to see you. If you impress them, if you do what I know you can, this movement will be up and running by tomorrow. And on the front page of the New York Times in six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She straightens his tie, directs him toward the lectern. hesitates....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tested the new bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We redesigned the timing mechanism. It can't possibly malfunction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, please. Just give your speech.... And nothing about Jews, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny steps to the lectern. The CROWD QUIETS. He stands silent for a long moment, then closes his eyes and chants with feeling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shema yisroel adonai elohenu adonai echod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General confusion. Mrs. Moebius and Curtis exchange wary glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows what that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Jewish prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can anybody imagine why I would say a Jewish prayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're a Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous laughter. Danny laughs with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That could be one reason. What's another? (no response) Let me put it this way...who here would like to destroy the Jews? (murmurs of approval) Who wants to grind their bones into the dust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scattering of applause, growing more sustained...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who wants to see them rise again, wealthier, more successful, powerful, cultured and intelligent than ever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. No one wants that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know what you have to do?... You have to love them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled mutterings: "What?... What's he talking about?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say love them? Love the Jews? It sounds strange, I know, but with these people nothing is simple. The Jew says that all he wants is to be left alone to study his Torah, do a little business and fornicate with his over-sexed wife.... But it isn't true. He wants to be hated. He longs for our scorn. He clings to it as if it were the very core and mystery of his being. If Hitler had not existed, the Jews would have invented him. For without such hatred, the so-called Chosen People would vanish from the earth....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People react with confusion, uncertainty, suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And this reveals a terrible truth, the crux of our problem as Nazis: the worse the Jews are treated, the stronger they become. Egyptian slavery made them a nation; the pogroms hardened them, Auschwitz gave birth to the State of Israel. Suffering, it seems, is the very crucible of their genius. If the Jews are, as one of their own has said, a people who will not take yes for an answer, then let us say yes to them. If they thrive on opposition, let us cease to oppose them. The way to annihilate them, utterly and completely, is to open our arms, take them into our homes and embrace them. Only then will they vanish into assimilation, dilution...and love. (a warning finger) But we cannot pretend. The Jew is nothing if not clever. He will see through condescension and hypocrisy. To destroy him, we will have to love him sincerely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE AUDIENCE, befuddled. A HAND goes up. Danny nods to The man steps forward, and we see that it's Guy Danielsen the Times. Danny is shaken....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if the Jews are strengthened by hate, wouldn't this "destruction" you speak of -- by love or by any other means -- in fact make them more powerful than they are already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Yes. Infinitely more. They would become as God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmurs of confusion, outrage... "God the TALLIS crawling out from under his shirt, stuffs it b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the Jews' destiny to the annihilated so that they can be deified.... (the murmurs swell) Jesus understood this perfectly. And look what was accomplished there with the death of just one enlightened Jew. Imagine what would happen if we killed them all!! (over the rising outrage) So, let us say together... Shema yisroel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One or two voices respond, but must people shout him down Mrs. Moebius is outraged. People are throwing things, shouting. The meeting degenerates into chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny talks to Mrs. Moebius. Offscreen we hear a TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just trying to make a point. If --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God... (calling) Lina...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm relieving you of all duties. I don't want you working for us anymore....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't. Do you know how many people I've brought into...the movement...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lina, come here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla watching a small TV on the kitchen counter. Danny arrives, followed by Lina and Curtis as we hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to police, he had just left the restaurant and was walking the block and a half back to his office, when the gunman stepped out of this doorway, fired seven times at point- blank range...then fled on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a terrible premonition) Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Moebius impatiently signals him to silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Paramedics arrived within ninety seconds, but Mr. Manzetti was declared dead at the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the mention of Manzetti's name, Danny goes white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilio Manzetti was one of the respected and influential men in New York. As an investment banker, diplomat, adviser to presidents and mayors, he helped shape public policy and private finance for more than three decades. He'll be missed, Phil. This is Michael Port with New York 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny's knees are weak, his hands cold, his stomach rises He becomes aware of the others, staring at him in amazeme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned) Do you think I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, please, we don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and Curtis walk out of the room. Stunned, shaken, Dan leaves in a different direction. The TV plays to an empty room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assailant is described as a white male in his late 20s....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny wanders out the door in a daze. His cell phone RING He has to search his pockets, then fumbles to turn it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finally killed a Jew, man. How's it feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle...I can't talk right now....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears a CAMERA SHUTTER and MOTOR DRIVE. He turns....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUY DANIELSEN & A PHOTOGRAPHER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're coming toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you kill Ilio Manzetti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Danny runs after the photographer, they struggle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the camera, don't hurt the camera...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny opens the camera, rips out the film, exposing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny glares at him without answering, walks away. Guy hurries after him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days ago you addressed a Nazi rally. Last week you went to a Torah study group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you, following me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you reconcile the two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't. Look, stay out of what you don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explain it so I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work for the New York Times. Your whole job in life is not to understand things like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you know what you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking on, fast) Yeah, and what are you? A Times man? A Presbyterian? Impotent? A prick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who killed Manzetti?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I tell you, will you pull the story? Not write about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late.... If I didn't, somebody else would. (as Danny just snorts) Yom Kippur starts at sundown. Will you go to synagogue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns on him, threatening) Get the fuck away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy backs off. Danny crosses the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Danny, just one more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances back. It's the PHOTOGRAPHER who has reloaded a now SNAPS a shot AS DANNY TURNS AWAY and keeps going....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Miriam walking together among the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're telling me you killed him? You? Killed him? Bullshit. What kind of gun did you use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guessing) A forty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a nine millimeter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you... But they'll believe you.... (as they walk) Lina Moebius is saying the whole thing was your idea. That you proposed it in a meeting at her house. (when he doesn't deny it) Ah, Jesus, Danny... What were you thinking? Are you glad Manzetti's dead? Do you really want to kill Jews? You want to kill me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just talking. I -- look, I can't help what I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know how to answer, walks away from her to the railing overlooking the water. He stares into the current flowing past. Finally Miriam joins him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, what if all along you were actually infiltrating the Nazis -- to expose them....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And only talked about killing Manzetti to convince them you were an anti-Semite. If you'd had any idea somebody would take it seriously, you never would have said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about your father. Your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth doesn't mean anything to you, does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, I'm trying to -- save you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her) Fucking kike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam is stung. She can't believe he said that. Still, s gets a small tape recorder out of her purse, hands it to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to get Lina Moebius on tape, telling you to do something. Something violent... That's right, I don't care about truth. I care about you. (looks at her watch) Kol Nidre's at six-thirty. I've got to meet Stuart. We'll be at the minyan tonight and tomorrow. If you need me, come there....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny watches her walk away, then turns to the railing. Ideally a FERRY is pulling away from its slip and heading out across the harbor. He watches it, then looks down at current moving past. He reaches a decision, throws the ta recorder into the water, turns and walks away....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny stops just inside the door. The place is spotless. desk has been pulled out from the wall, covered with a sn cloth and set for a Sabbath meal: brass candelabrum, chal under a satin cover...and two place settings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carla is pouring wine into the kiddush cup. She's wearing modest dress, her hair is pinned up with a piece of lace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, startled; she hadn't heard him come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's erev Yom Kippur.... We'll have dinner, then go to shul. Atone for our sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a couple of olives off the table, eats them as h goes through his closet, stuffing a couple things in a ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we can be like Eichmann. He studied Torah. He hated Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the closet, looking) Is it like Eichmann? Are we goofing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just want to try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit... (looking in other places) Did you talk to your mother today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (indicates table as he keeps looking) Why are you doing this? (back to the closet) I thought God didn't exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He commands it whether He exists or not... (off his silence; with difficulty) Look, we can fight him and be crushed. Or we can submit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the closet) And be crushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. But what if...what if... submitting...being crushed, being nothing, not mattering, what if that's the best feeling we can have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds it (a kittel), stuffs it in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, just light the candles with me. Then we'll eat. You have to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You eat first, then you light. (exasperated, he has to explain) Once you light, it's Yom Kippur, which means you're fasting, so you can't...eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trails off, looks at her. She's everything he ever wan and he's already lost her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman of valor, who can find her? Her price is above rubies....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out, leaving the door open. Carla starts to call after him, but then doesn't. She turns back, lights the candles and awkwardly reads the prayers....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny on a phone. Behind him, Jews hurry home for the holiday. He hears a BEEP...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam, it's me, Danny.... Come on, the holiday hasn't started, pick up the -- (as someone does) ...Is Stuart davening Ne'ilah tomorrow at the minyan... 'Cause he always does... Tell him I'm doing it instead....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She argues (we hear her VOICE not her words)...Danny cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam, I'm davening.... He gives me any trouble, I'll beat the shit out of him right there in the room. I'm serious....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still talking when he hangs up and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lina and Curtis with Billings and Drake, who looks bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (never considered it) I was hurt. I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went to his friends' place and I laid up there 'til he was better. Then he called me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've gone to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Drake wants to talk to the police. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of him myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Curtis answers, listens, covers the mout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Balint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes it with a dramatic gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes the phone) Hello...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lina... It's happening. Tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth Shalom. Like you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth Shalom? What are you talking about? Who is this...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lina, you said if I was going to plant a bomb, I should --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLICK as she hangs up. He's pleased. He steps away from the phone. He's carrying a grease-stained bag and is acro from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEMPLE EMANU-EL...KOL NIDRE being sung by a soprano withi and ORGAN accompanying her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the synagogue across the street we hear KOL NIDRE bein sung by a soprano; an ORGAN accompanying her. Danny looks at the temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up as the Nazi sergeant holds the boy on the bayo over the father's head. But now Danny is the father, and father is the sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lunges at the Nazi, knocking him down, tearing at this throat. The sergeant screams....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in German, to his fellows) Kill him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny bites through the Nazi's jugular as bullets rip int

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle's car is parked on the Central Park side of Fifth....Danny gets in the passenger side. Kyle is behind the wheel, wiring an explosive device. Danny hands him th grease-stained bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle holds up a solitary pipe bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all we've got left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be enough if we use it right. (checks his watch) Okay, the service'll go about another hour. Say an hour for the janitors, then one more just to be safe... We'll go in at midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle has extracted a cheeseburger and shake from the bag. he starts in on them, he realizes Danny isn't eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you get anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not hungry.... Come on, let's drive around.... We don't want to be spotted here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating, Kyle starts the car, pulls away....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (white with fury) He is trying to set us up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curtis picks up a cell phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Drake and Billings) I want him dead by tomorrow night. That lies within your capacities, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billings nods. Drake unconsciously licks the center of hi lower lip. As they leave, we see that he limps horribly. When they're gone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, I believe that a bomb is going to be planted tonight at Temple Emanu-el on 65th Street.... By the same man who killed Ilio Manzetti... His name is Daniel Balint....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV inside van. Fifth is quiet. Temple Emanu-el again, straight ahead. But now we see SECURITY GUARDS near the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what is this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep driving. Don't slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV speeds up, whips past the synagogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said they didn't have night guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't. I checked twenty times.... Somebody must have talked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who even knew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Moebius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why would she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manzetti thing must have scared her. She thinks she'll get implicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do we do with the device?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Plaza straight ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a right on 59th... (as the car turns) We'll put it someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an idea....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pencil-beam flashlight moves through the darkness. We follow it. The light enters a space where SOUND ECHOES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PENCIL BEAM shows Kyle on his back attaching the bomb t some kind of wooden floor cupboard. He's worried about th paltry amount of explosives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all reinforced in here. It's not going to blow out the way we want it....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny is too preoccupied flipping through a machzor to an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I went back to the lumberyard, the guy'd give me all the dynamite I wanted. Untraceable, you wouldn't -- need to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it has to be tomorrow. You won't get this many of them in here for another year. It'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not going to be fine. It's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle sighs, goes about doing it, he HEARS SOMETHING and f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny clicks off the light. A SILHOUETTE on the windows..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just somebody on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
